p.seg: 35 "For cultivating the heart-and-mind nothing is betterthan lessening one's desires.
In the case of a man who haslessened his desires,
there may be occasions when he doesnot keep the faith,
but they will be rare.
In the case of a manof many desires,
there may be occasions when he keeps thefaith,
but they will be rare."
13 Lu wanted to put Yiieh-cheng K'o in charge of the government,
and Mencius spoke up,
"When I heard that,
I could not sleep for joy."
Kung-sun Ch'ou then asked,
"is he energetic?"
"No."
"Is he wise and foresighted?*
"No."
"Has he had a lot of experience?"
"No."
"Then why were you so happy that you could not sleep?"
"As a man, he is fond of goodness."
"Is that sufficient for the task at hand?"
"Love of goodness is more than enough to qualify forruling the world;
so how much the more for ruling the stateof Lu?
If he is fond of goodness,
the whole world
will makelight of a thousand kilometers
in order to come and bearwitness to the goodness.
If, however, he were not fond ofgoodness,
people would say, 'Yes, yes;
we already know abouthim.'
That yes-yes tone of voice and complexion
will keeppeople a thousand kilometers away.
If gentlemen stay a thousandkilometers away,
calumniators, flatterers, and adulatorswill come.
And when you are living with such people
do youthink that you can bring order to a slate
even if you wantto?"
25 Hao-sheng Pu-hai inquired,
"What sort of man is Yiiehcheng K'o?"
"An approved man;
one who inspires confidence."
"What do you mean?"
"The desirable is called approved;
and to contain within Mencius 7B 161oneself is to inspire confidence.
When filled fully with both of these, one is called handsome.
When filled fully with themto the point of being glorious, one is called great.
When out of greatness one produces changes in the world, one is called a sage.
What remains unknown despite the fact that one is a sage is called divine.
Yiieh-cheng K'o
qualifies for thefirst two,
but is under par for the last four."
4 All creation may be attaining a completion in ourselves,
but there is no greater joy than the discovery that we aresincere.
"Act with a mighty adherence to the Golden Rule,
for whenseeking manhood-at-its-best nothing approximates it more."
...but there is no greater joy...
3 'If a thing can be gotten by seeking
and lost by neglect,
then the very act of seeking is contributing to success,
andthe thing sought is an internal, the virtues naturally inherentto man.
If the seeking must follow a particular procedure
and success depends upon Fate,
then the act of seeking contributesnothing to the success,
and the thing sought is anexternal, like salary."
5 'To act without knowing why;
to do a thing habituallywithout examining the reasons;
to pursue an activity all lifelong without understanding inherent Process—
this is to beone of the crowd."
6 ^'Man must have a sense of shame.
Having once beenashamed of its absence,
he will have it always."
1 "By using all the heart-and-mind
one understands nature;
and then one understands Sky. B
y preserving the heart-and-mind
and nurturing nature
one serves Sky.
Either prematuredeath or longevity being sure,
one cultivates his own personand awaits one or the other.
That is why we postulateFate."
2 ^^Everything is controlled by Fate,
so in all humility acceptit in its normal form.
Accordingly, the man who understandsFate
will not stand at the foot of a towering wall.
To die after fulfilling all that was incumbent upon us
is to experiencea normal Fate.
Death in fetters
is not a normal Fate."
31 "For every man there is something that is intolerable.
When that attitude is extended to what they do find tolerable,
manhood-at-its-best is being practiced.
For every man there is something that he will not do.
When that attitude is extended to what he does do,
propriety is being practiced.
*lf humans could fill full that attitude of theirs which has no desire to harm others,
the amount of manhood-at-its-best around here would be inexhaustible.
If humans could fill full that attitude of theirs which is free of all short-selling,
the amount of propriety around here would be inexhaustible.
If humans could fill full that state of theirs where they are not addressed by the second-person pronoun,
they would be treated with propriety wherever they went.
"If a gentleman addresses a person of distinction before he has the right to do so,
he is trying to attract him with his words.
If he does not address him when he has the right to do so,
he is trying to attract him with silence.
In both of these cases he is selling short."
32 ^^Discourse which is simple but profound,
is good discourse.
What is succinct but vast in effects,
is good procedure.
"When Great Man speaks,
since all that he says comes from the heart,
it will be found that Process is in his words.
When Great Man is in charge,
he improves his own person
and the whole world becomes serene.
"Humans complain of those who abandon their own field
and weed the field of others.
They complain of a situation where much is demanded of others
while little is being required of oneself."
15 "Having studied a thing widely and expounded it in detail,
one can reverse himself and expound it succinctly."
16 "The strategist and strongest
have never been conquerors of men.
But if one knows how to support others,
the whole world can be subdued.
Nobody has ever become real king
...unless the whole world was submissive to him in its heart-and-mind."...
12 ^If the prince cannot be believed,
what are we to hold fast to?"
15 ^^The abilities which a man possesses naturally and withoutstudy
are the highest type of ability;
what he knowswithout reflection
is the highest type of knowledge.
Thus, allbabies who are smiled at and hugged
will know how to lovethe members of their families,
and when they grow up
theywill know how to respect their elders.
Now, since treatingthe family as the family
should be treated is manhood-at-its best;
and since respect for elders
is propriety,
it only remainsfor us
to spread these virtues throughout the world! Nothingelse need be done!"
12 "An important man
is one who has not lost his childlikeheart-and-mind.
words are not necessarilytruthful
and actions are not necessarily fruitful.
Heresides solely in propriety."
13 "Supporting of parents
may not he considered an importantundertaking,
but their funeral is."
14 "Great Man wishes to attain a firm hold upon right procedureby going deeply into its problems;
he desires to attain it as a personal experience,
and when that is achieved he feels himself dwelling securely in it.
When he has it as a profound resource, he uses it as he comes upon it bubbling up on allsides.
That is why Great Man wishes it to be a personal acquisition."
17 ^It bodes only ill when words are not rooted in fact.
Afact which bodes only ill
is the concealing of those of the highest caliber."
18 Hsü P'i said,
"Confucius often spoke in praise of water[6.23],
*Ah, water,
water!'
What value did he find in water?"
"A spring just bubbles and bubbles,
and never stops day or night.
It advances only after filling in the holes,
and then goes on to the seas.
This is water acting its best,
and this isall Confucius meant by it.
But water can also misbehave.
In the seventh and eighth moons
the rain gathers
and the canalsare all filled,
but a drying up
can be expected momentarily.T
hat is why Great Man would be ashamed were his reputation to surpass the facts in his situation."
...would be ashamed...
19 "It is only a trifle that differentiates man from the birdsand beasts.
Ordinary people lose that trifle,
but Great Man preserves it.
Shun had a clear understanding of the mass of creation;
he had observed the duties incumbent upon man.
He acted through manhood-at-its-best and propriety;
he did not make those two virtues current.
2 Kung-sun Ch'ou put this question: ^^Master, if you wereto become chief minister in Ch'i and succeed in makingyour procedures operative there,
it is very possible that
you would succeed in creating nothing more than a hegemonclaiming to be real king.
Does the thought of this possibilitydisturb you?"
"No.
I am forty, and imperturbable."
"In that case
you far surpass the goliath Meng Pen.
"That isn't difficult. "
"That isn't difficult.
Kao Pu-hai attained imperturbabilityahead of me."
"Yes.
Look at how Pei-kung Yu nourished valor:
When adagger thrust was made at his skin, he did not dodge;
when made at his eye, there was not even a blink.
His ideawas that a hair torn from a man
was no different from aflogging in the open market place.
He would accept no morefrom the prince of a powerful state than from an outcast.
He looked upon the stabbing of the prince of a powerfulstate
as no different from the stabbing of an outcast.
Hewas unawed in the presence of a feudal lord.
When cursed,
he swore back.
Then there is what Meng Shih-she has toldus of his own nourishing of valor:
In my eyes victory anddefeat are indifferent.
To advance only after determining thesize of the opposition,
and to join battle only after all precautionshave been taken for victory
—this is to fear themass of the opposing forces.
Can I personally so act asto assure victory?
No. All I can do is be fearless.'
Thus MengShih-she resembles Tseng Ts'an
and Pei-kung Yu resemblesPu Shang,
and it is not yet known
whose valor was thebetter,
but Meng Shih-she possessed all the essentials.
"Of old, Tseng Ts'an once said to Tzu-hsiang, his pupil
'You like the topic of valor.
Well, I once learned aboutreal valor from Confucius.
If on self-examination I am founddeficient in poise,
I shall not frighten even an outcast.
Butif I am found to have a firm grasp on poise,
I will advanceagainst even a thousand or a myriad men.'
So Tseng Ts'an'spreservation of the essentials
is to be preferred to MengShih-she's preservation of his Vitality."
"Would you mind telling me
about your own and KaoPu-hai's imperturbability?"
"Kao Pu-hai has said,
'Do not seek in your heart forwhat you do not find in your words.
Do not seek in yourVitality for what you do not find in your heart.'
Thesecond of these statements I find to be all right;
the first,I disapprove.
For will is commander over the Vitality,
while Vitality is what fills our persons.
Will is of the highest importance;
Vitality stands second.
That is why it is said,'
There is no disorder in the Vitality where will ismaintained.'"
"How can this last statement hold when you have just said, *Will is of the highest importance;
Vitality stands second?'"
"If the will is unified, it becomes a motor for the Vitality.
If the Vitality is the unified one, it becomes motor for thewill.
Take these fellows who stumble and rush about;
this isthe Vitality acting as motor,
and in turn it becomes themotor for their hearts-and-minds."
"May I ask what your strong point is?"
"I know the significance of what is being said;
and I knowhow to nourish my Overwhelming Vitality."
"What do you mean by 'Overwhelming Vitality'?"
"This is hard to put into words.
It is
so that if it is correctly nourished and suffersno damage,
the hugest and thefirmest thing,
it becomes contained only by Sky and Earth.
It is
the peer of propriety and right procedure,
but withoutthem it would starve.
It is the source of all our acts of propriety,
it is not something that propriety sneaks up upon andseizes.
If an action produces no satisfaction in the heart-and-mind,
this Vitality will perish of starvation.
That is why wesay
'Kao Pu-hai has never understood propriety
because hethinks of it as an external.' [6A4]
"Propriety is something to be practiced;
do not try tobrace it up into existence!
Let it be constantly in yourheart-and-mind,
and do not engage in efforts to helpit grow!
Do not do like the man in Sung.
A certain manof Sung was dejected because his new shoots were notlengthening fast enough,
so he stretched them.
Then hehastened back home and said to his folks,
I'm all faggedout today.
I've been helping the shoots to lengthen.'
Thenhis son ran out to have a look at them.
What had beenshoots were now dead straws.
There are few people in theworld who do not try to help the shoots lengthen!
Thenthere are those who, seeing no advantage in the work, justabandon them;
they are the ones who do not cultivate theshoots.
Those that try to help them get longer
are the oneswho stretch them;
and this is not only of no advantage tothe shoots,
it even damages them."
"What did you mean when you said, I know the significanceof what is being said'?"
"Inexact speech shows that something is being concealed;
unrestrained speech, that something is being ensnared;
evilspeech, that discord is being created;
does damage to government,
evasive speech, thatsomething is being eliminated.
What arises in the heart-and-mind
and orders issued bygovernment
can damage the business at hand.
When a sageagain appears,
he will certainly abide by my words.
"Tsai Yii and Tuan-mu Tz'u [11.3] knew how tophrase their thoughts.
Jan Keng, Min Sun, and Yen Hui knewhow to talk about the practice of Excellence.
And Confuciuscombined both these capacities.
But I have no ability as atalker."
*'So you have become a sage!"
What sort of talk is this!
Of old, Tuan-mu Tz'uasked Confucius,
"Oh!
'Is the Master a sage?',
and Confucius[7.34,2] answered, '
If it is a question of sagehood, I donot qualify.
I am a person who studies insatiably andteaches unweariedly.'
And Tuan-mu Tz'u continued.
Tostudy insatiably
is wisdom;
and to teach unweariedly
is to beman-at-his-best.
Being wise and also man-at-his-best,
youare already a sage!'
So what sort of talk is this, when Confuciushimself would not admit to being a sage!
Long ago Iwas taught this:
Pu Shang, Yen Yen, and Chuan-sun Shih
each possessed one limb of the sage; J
an Keng, Min Sun, andYen Hui
possessed the whole body, but in miniature only."
"May I inquire where you fit in?"
"Let's leave that question for the moment."
"What were Po-i and I-yin like?"
"They were not of the same type.
Po-i [2A9] was a manwho would not serve a prince of whom he disapproved,
would not employ subjects of whom he disapproved;
if goodorder prevailed, he would come forward;
in times of disorder,he would not come forward.
I-yin was a man who saw noharm in serving a prince of whom he disapproved
or in employingsubjects of whom he disapproved;
he came forwardwhether good order or disorder reigned.
Confucius was aman who served when it was proper;
stayed in retirementwhen it was proper;
tarried when it was proper;
and leftquickly when it was proper.
Personally, I have not yet been able to do what theydid,
but if it is a question of my desire,
These three were sages of longago.
I will take Confuciusas my model."
"Would you then put Po-i and I-yin
in the same classas Confucius?"
"No.
Ever since creation
there has been no one thatI would class with Confucius."
"In that case, did these three have anything in common?"
"If any one of the three,
possessing 100 kilometers ofterritory, had become the lord of it,
he could have summonedall the feudal lords to his court and thus gained thewhole world.
But not a one of them would have committeda solitary act of impropriety
or slain a solitary innocentman
to gain the world.
This they had in common."
"May I ask in what they differed?"
"Tsai Yii, Tuan-mu Tz'u, and Yu Jo
were sufficiently wiseto recognize a sage;
they would not have stooped to flattersomeone of whom they were fond.
Accordingly, Tsai Yiiis quoted as saying,
'From my point of view Confucius
isof far higher caliber than Yao or Shun.'
Tuan-mu Tz'u putit this way:
'A ruler can be known from the ceremonies hefollows;
his Excellence can be known from the music heplays:
this principle will hold for the last hundred rulers.
Hence we know that from creation on
there has never beenanother Confucius.'
Yu Jo expressed it:
'Shall we speak onlyof the subjects of a state?
The unicorn is of a species withthe four-footed animals; t
he phoenix, with the birds that fly;
Mount T'ai, with mounds and ant hills;
rivers and oceans,with tiny streams.
And sages are of a species with the subjectsof a state.
But as for those who rise above their species
and stand out above their groups,
since creation
there hasbeen none superior to Confucius.'"
17 "Do not have done what you yourself would not do;
do not have desired what you yourself would not desire.
It is as simple as that."
1 Pupil Kao Pu-hai argued thus:
''Man's nature is analogous to the willow wood,
while propriety
may be said to be analogous to a cup or bowl.
Manhood-at-its-best and propriety are made from man's nature
in the same way that cups or bowls are made from willow wood."
"Yes, but you cannot maintain the original nature of the willow wood and at the same time make cups and bowls of it!
These you will make only after doing violence to the willow wood!
So will you in this same way do violence to a human being in order to make manhood-at-its-best and propriety of him?
So will you in this same way do violence to a human being in order to make manhood-at-its-best and propriety of him?
It is certainly words like yours—not so?—that will lead everybody in the world to think of manhood-at-its-best and propriety as calamities!"
2 Kao:
''Well, then, let us compare man's nature
to a torrent of water.
Breach its eastern bank and it will flow east;
breach the western, and it will flow west.
And further, man's nature is not divided into good and evil
any more than water is divided into east and west."
*'It is true that water is not divided into east and west,
but it certainly is divided into high or low!
I should say that man's nature is naturally good
in the same way that water naturally seeks its lowest level.
There is no human being who is not good,
just as there is no water that does not seek the lowest level.
It is possible to strike water
and thus cause it to splash higher than your forehead;
or by dikes it can be moved
and caused to remain on a mountain;
but this is not water's nature!
It does such things only if force has been applied.
And the same type of thing has happened to man's nature when he becomes evil."
3 Kao:
"Life itself is what is meant by the word nature.''
"Is that the same as saying
anything white may be called white?"
"Yes."
"Then is the white applied to white feathers
the sameas the white applied to white snow,
and is the white ofthe latter
the same as the white of white jade?"
"Yes."
"In that case then wouldn't the nature of dogs
be similar to the nature of buffaloes,
and wouldn't the nature of the latter
be similar to the nature of men? It is obvious that your definition is wrong!"
4 Kao:
"Eating and the sexual instinct
are what we mean by nature."
On another occasion he said, "Manhood-at-its-best
is an internal, i
t is not an external;
whereas propriety
is an external,
it is not an internal." [2A2]
"Why do you say that?"
"Once an elder is present, I treat him as an elder should be treated;"
or in the one who is treating the elderly the way they should be treated?"

Therefore, we ourselves are the reagents[sic!],

But I treat the elders of the man from Ch'u as elders should be treated,

Therefore, since elderliness is the reagent,

"My fondness for the roast belonging to the man fromCh'in
cannot be differentiated from fondness for my own roast.
Whenever the object itself is there the same reaction is produced.
Would you, therefore, conclude that fondness for roast is external?"
5 Pupil Meng Chi questioned pupil Kung-tu:
"Why do you say that propriety is internal?"
"I carry out a respect which I feel.
Therefore, I call it internal."
"If a fellow townsman were one year older than your oldest elder brother,
whom would you respect the more?"
"My elder brother."
"If serving wine, whom would you serve first?"
"The townsman."
"Well, then, since the objects of your respect can be situated in space,
propriety is an external;
Kung-tu could not answer him,
so he reported the conversation to Mencius,
who suggested this:
"Put it to him this way. Who gets the greater respect from you,
your uncle or your younger brother?
He will say,
my uncle.
Well,suppose your younger brother is playing the role of the departed ancestor at the service,
who gets the preference then?
He will say,
my younger brother.
Well, what happened to your preferential treatment of your uncle?
it is due to the position occupied.
He will say,
So you now have your answer for Meng Chi.
Normally the chief respect is shown to the eldest brother,
but there will be occasions when it is shown to the townsman."
Although he listened to this report, Meng Chi still concluded,
"It is respect that is being shown whether to an uncle
And it is external;
or to a younger brother.
it is not from the inside."
Kung-tu:
"If it is a winter day you drink hot broth;
and if it is a summer day you drink water.
Therefore, drinking and eating are also externals!"
6 Kong-tu:
"Kao says
that the nature is neutral, it is neither good nor evil.
Others say
that it is influenced either to good
or to evil,
and that that is why subjects werefond of goodness under the good kings Wen and Wu,
while under the bad kings Yu and Li they were addicted to violence.
Others argue
that some natures are good
and some natures are evil,
and that that is why under the sage Yao there could be an evil person like Hsiang,
while despite an evil father like Ku-sou there could be a paragon like Shun.
Despite that evil person Chou, who became king because he was the son of an elder brother,
there could be such fine persons as Ch'i, the Viscount of Wei, and Prince Pi-kan.
...who became king...
But you, Mencius, keep saying that the nature is good.
Are all these others wrong?"
"If attention is paid to the way it feels within oneself,
the nature really can be considered good.
And that is what I mean when I call it good.
If it can be influenced to evil,
that is not the fault of its innate capacity.
"All human beings possess a sense of compassion,
just as they all possess a sense of shame,
a sense of reverence,
and a sense of right and wrong.
The sense of compassion
is manhood-at-its-best.
The sense of shame
is propriety.
The sense of reverence
is ceremony.
The sense of right and wrong
is knowledge.
Manhood-at-its-best, propriety, ceremony,and knowledge
are not brazed on to us from the outside;
we just possess them.
But we do not always think of them.
That is why it is said
that if one seeks them they
but, if neglected, they are lost.
To be sure, somehave twice as much of this endowment as others, some five times as much, and some incalculably more,
but its innate capacity can never be exhausted.
Remember The Poems[260]:
*Sky gave birth to the whole multitude of subjects,
they have bodies and they have innate laws.
While the subjects cling to the norm,
they will be fond of this fair Excellence.'
And Confucius once remarked,
The author of this poem
really understood Process!'
Therefore, for everything in nature these needs must be an innate law which governs it.
Because the subjects cling to the norm,
theyare fond of this fair Excellence."
7 'In good years
the younger members of our group, for the most part, can be counted on;
in bad years,
they turn to violence.
It is not that they vary because of the capacity conferred by Sky;
it is because their hearts-and-mindsbecome entrapped or drowned by conditions.
It is the same as with barley.
The seed is sown and covered.
If the sites are of equal fertility
and the times of sowing are identical,
it will shoot right up,
and at the solstice
it will all be ripe.
If there are any differences,
they will be due to differences in the fertility of the sites,
or to variations in rain and dew,
or to inequalities in the care bestowed by humans.
So, since everything of the same species
resembles one another,
why doubt the resemblance only in the case of the human being?
The sage and I are of the same species.
That is why Lungtzu could say,
If sandals are made even when the particular feet which will wear them are unknown,
I know that baskets will not be made;
for sandals resemble one another
because all feet in the world are similar.'
"It is the same as with tastes,
where mouths share the same delights.
Yi Wu was the first one to achieve what our mouths delight in.
If in regard to taste the nature of mouths
differed from individual to individual,
the way dogs and horses differ from us,
how would the world's delights
all follow Yi Wu in the matter of taste?
If in regard to taste
the whole world waits upon the decision of Yi Wu,
it means that the mouths of the world resemble one another.
"Even in the case of ears it is like that too.
If in thematter of music
the whole world waits upon the decision of Maestro K'uang,
it means that the ears of the world resembleone another.
Even in the case of eyes it is like that too.
Everybody in the world knows that Tu is handsome.
Anybody who does not
is eyeless.
So I put it this way:
Since in the matter of taste
mouths share the same delights,
and in the matter of music
and in the matter of beauty
ears all appreciate the same things,
eyes all praise the same thing,
why should it be only in the case of the heart-and-mind
that there is nothing shared in common?
What is it that hearts-and-mindshave in common?
Reason
and propriety.
It is merely that the sages were the first to attain
what our hearts-and-mindshave in common.
Hence, reason and propriety please our minds
in just the same way that grass-fed and grain-fedmeats please our mouths."
8 "The trees on Ox Hill were once beautiful,
but owing to its proximity to a large city
hatchets and axes cut at them,
so how could they remain beautiful?
Then with the increases in growth going on day and night
and the watering from rain and dew,
some growth of shoots did occur there.
But then the cattle and sheep resorted there for pasture.
That is why it is deserty looking,
and noticing the deserty appearance
people think that there was never any wood there.
But is this the true nature of the mountain?
So even in the case of what is in man,
can we possibly say that he does not contain a heart-and-mind marked with manhood-at-its-bestand propriety?
The way in which he lays aside his heart-and-mind in its excellent state
may be compared to the wayin which hatchets and axes have treated trees.
How can the beauty remain when they are cut day after day?
But then too in the case of men's hearts-and-minds there occurs an increaseof growth both day and night
which we recognize as the air of dawn
and whose likes and dislikes are quite similar among all men.
But then what is done all day long
puts this good air in shackles or destroys it.
If it is shackled repeatedly,
that air which can accumulate overnight cannot be maintained;
and in that case man finds himself not farremoved from the condition of birds and beasts.
Then observing the animality in himself,
man comes to think that he never contained any other capacity.
But is animality man's proper feeling?
Therefore, we conclude that anything that is nurtured
will grow;
anything that is not,
will melt away.
Was it a reference to the heart-and-mind when Confucius said,
*If you hold it firmly, it will be kept;
if you release it, it will be lost.
The comings and goings are irregular,
...Was it a reference to the heart-and-mind...
nobody knows where it lodges'?"
